title: Derek Chauvin Verdict: Across America, Cheers, Then Calls to Action
sub_head: Many herald verdict as a victory in effort to combat police violence against people of color, although several said there is still work to do
body:
In a parking lot in Atlanta, on the street in Washington, D.C., and in a living room in Minneapolis, Americans across the country paused at 4:05 p.m. Central Time on Tuesday afternoon to look at their TV sets and cellphones and learn that Derek Chauvin was found guilty in the murder of George Floyd.
Many heralded the verdict as a victory in the effort to combat police violence against people of color, although several added that there was still more work to be done. The president of the nation’s largest police union said justice had worked as it should.
Amarachi Bruce listened to the verdict on her cellphone outside a beauty- supply store in Atlanta, near the site of a Wendy’s restaurant where Rayshard Brooks was shot and killed by a police officer last June.
“If I am being honest, I never thought he would be convicted,” said Ms. Bruce, an 18-year-old Georgia State University student. She said she hoped that the U.S. was beginning to awaken to the problem of police mistreatment of Black people.
Politicians and companies weighed in as well.
